title: The 2021 Legislature’s last-minute laws
excerpt: Most of the new laws passed by the 2021 Legislature spent weeks moving through a public process. These are the key provisions that didn’t.

title: Winners, losers and mixed bags of the 67th Montana Legislature
excerpt: After four months of finagling, these are the winners, losers and mixed bags of the 67th Montana Legislature.

title: Vaccination bill moves closer to law, with changes
excerpt: Montana’s ongoing debate over prohibiting vaccination requirements took several twists Wednesday after Gov. Greg Gianforte sent House Bill 702 back to the Legislature with proposed changes of his own. Hours later, the House voted 65-35 to accept those changes.

title: Effort to investigate environmental groups voted down
excerpt: A measure that would have directed the Department of Justice to investigate environmental groups is likely dead.

title: Marijuana bill passes House
excerpt: House Bill 701, introduced by Rep. Mike Hopkins, R-East Missoula, and backed by Gov. Gianforte, passed its third and final reading in the House on a bipartisan 67-32 vote, ending a month of debate in Helena about how to implement Initiative 190, which legalized adult-use cannabis last November.

title: Ban on vax requirements headed for governor’s desk
excerpt: Lawmakers have passed a bill that prohibits COVID-19 and other vaccination requirements in Montana after receiving assurances from the governor’s office that the law won’t impact hospital visitation. Hospitals aren’t so certain.

title: Montana Republicans want to limit abortion access. It won’t be easy.
excerpt: The state Supreme Court has long affirmed that privacy matters more than politics. The Republican-led Legislature is trying to change that.

title: The Session podcast

nodes.name: Special Select Committee on Judicial Transparency and Accountability

excerpt: What we’re looking forward to in week 17 of the Montana Legislature: last-minute legislation and maneuvering.

title: This week in Helena, April 19-23
excerpt: A roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, from a voting rights lawsuit to financial reimbursements for wolf hunters.

title: Colstrip Sen. Duane Ankney revives part of NorthWestern Energy bill
excerpt: The Senate Natural Resources Committee voted Friday to revive part of a controversial bill that sought to guarantee regulated utility monopolies like NorthWestern Energy a rate of return on new coal-fired power by weakening the Public Service Commission’s oversight.

title: Trans athlete restriction bill clears Montana Legislature
excerpt: Lawmakers on Friday passed a bill, largely along party lines, that would prohibit girls and women who are transgender from participating on women’s school sports teams.

title: Vaccine mandates: truth, fiction, and unknowns
excerpt: Legislative proceedings stoked questions and concerns about COVID-19 vaccine requirements in Montana. Who is — and who isn’t — mandating vaccination, how strict are those policies, and how might HB 702 muddy the mix?

title: GOP lawmakers put brakes on controversial energy bill
excerpt: Senate Bill 379, which would have greased the wheels for more Colstrip investment by NorthWestern Energy at ratepayer expense, dies in committee.

title: Election law changes spark lawsuit
excerpt: The Montana Democratic Party is attempting to block changes to voting rights laws signed by Gov. Greg Gianforte.

title: Political appointees bill voted down in Senate
excerpt: Amendments scaling back a bill that would have boosted the number of political appointees in state agencies weren’t enough to get it past the finish line in the state Senate, where it failed a final vote Tuesday.

title: Split movement for bills restricting transgender youth and athletes
excerpt: Montana lawmakers on Tuesday advanced one bill curtailing the rights of transgender student athletes and voted to indefinitely postpone another bill that would restrict certain medical care for minors with gender dysphoria.

title: ‘A highly unusual forum’
excerpt: All seven Montana Supreme Court justices made virtual appearances Monday before a joint legislative committee investigating alleged bias in the judiciary, even as they maintained they weren’t necessarily subject to legislative subpoenas. The atypical exchange marked the latest development in a thorny power struggle between Montana’s legislative and judicial branches.

title: Gianforte approves changes to Montana election laws
excerpt: Gov. Greg Gianforte has officially ended the state’s long-standing practice of allowing citizens to register to vote on Election Day, a change he said will help preserve the integrity of Montana’s elections, but that critics have decried as a blatant attack on voter rights.

title: The Session podcast

nodes.name: Select Committee on Transparency and Accountability

excerpt: What we’re looking forward to in week 16 of the Montana Legislature: Separation of powers and the future of Colstrip.

title: This week in Helena, April 12-16
excerpt: A roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, from regulatory takings to immunity passports.

title: COVID closes the Capitol
excerpt: Lawmakers abruptly postponed Friday floor sessions in response to a positive COVID-19 case inside the Capitol. Here’s what happened, and how it affects the Legislature’s schedule.

title: Republicans target alleged bias in Supreme Court crisis
excerpt: A challenge to the Legislature’s judicial appointment law spirals into a Republican-led investigation of the Montana judiciary over missing records. Democrats call it a ‘witch hunt’ designed to smear the judicial branch.

title: Religious exemption revived in committee
excerpt: Senate Bill 162 would have exempted religious organizations from the state’s campaign reporting requirements. It was tabled in mid-March. Now it’s back, piggybacked onto a new bill just days before a key legislative deadline.

title: Legislature passes black bear, grizzly bear and wolf proposals
excerpt: Three proposals that seek to change how bears and wolves are managed in Montana passed out of the Legislature Wednesday on largely Republican support. The bills headed to Gov. Greg Gianforte’s desk in the coming weeks illustrate a deep divide between how Republican and Democratic lawmakers think about managing predators in the state.

title: Increased shelter access for homeless youth shut down in committee
excerpt: House lawmakers on the Human Services Committee tabled a bill on Tuesday that would allow minors to stay in emergency shelters and receive services without the consent of a parent or guardian, a measure proponents have said is crucial for the protection of vulnerable youth seeking safe harbor from dangerous living situations.

title: Lawmakers reject extra vetting for public assistance programs

nodes.name: Department of Public Health and Human Services

excerpt: A bill that could have interrupted health care coverage for thousands of low-income Montanans, and would have added additional hurdles for people enrolled in public assistance programs, was tabled in a House committee on Monday with bipartisan support.

title: Income tax overhaul in the mix
excerpt: A late-session Republican bill would rework much of Montana’s tax system in the name of simplification, while lowering tax rates on high earners and eliminating some existing tax credits.

title: Property rights v. public good
excerpt: A new ‘regulatory takings’ bill aims to give citizens a path to reimbursement for value lost due to government regulation. Critics say it could gut the state’s ability to enforce environmental and public health rules.

title: Legislature overrides Gianforte’s first veto
excerpt: A vote in the Montana House finalizes a veto override of a bill giving the Legislature more power over rulemaking at state agencies. It’s likely the first time since 2003 lawmakers have successfully challenged a Montana governor’s veto.

title: Next steps for bills regulating birth certificates and transgender athletes
excerpt: House lawmakers voted Monday to advance a bill that would make it more difficult for residents to update the gender on their birth certificates, and rerouted another measure banning girls and women who are transgender from playing on women’s sports teams.

title: Snares legalized and trapping season expanded
excerpt: Gianforte signs two wolf management bills into law, with more likely headed to his desk.

title: Clearing out a confidentiality clause
excerpt: Ethics complaints are no longer confidential in Montana after Gianforte signs Missoula Rep. Brad Tschida’s ‘Bullock-Brad Battle Bill.’

title: The Session podcast
excerpt: What we’re looking forward to in week 15 of the Montana Legislature: parental rights and competing tax bills for adult-use marijuana.

title: This week In Helena, April 5-9
excerpt: MTFP’s roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, from the state budget to tax policy and energy bills.

title: Unanimous Senate votes to override Gianforte’s first veto
excerpt: Montana’s Senate voted unanimously Friday to override the first veto issued by Gov. Greg Gianforte, defending a bill that would make it easier for the Legislature to repeal administrative rules issued by state agencies.

title: The financial side of school choice
excerpt: A pair of legislative proposals would rewrite how the state funds educational opportunities for students. Supporters say they want to give Montanans more choices, while opponents argue the changes threaten to steer public dollars to private religious institutions.

title: NorthWestern Energy bill moves toward final approval in Senate
excerpt: Senate Bill 379, which has been referred to as a “wish list for NorthWestern Energy,” passed a critical vote this week with near-unanimous GOP support.

title: Marijuana bills roll through the House
excerpt: A trio of bills to regulate recreational marijuana could be heading to the Senate this week after a series of votes by House lawmakers on Tuesday.

title: Bill could make hundreds of state workers political appointees
excerpt: House Bill 588 would expand the number of political appointment jobs in state government. Opponents worry about politicizing bureaucracy.

title: The Session podcast
excerpt: What we’re looking forward to in week 14 of the Montana Legislature: piecing together the budget puzzle.

title: This week in Helena, March 29–April 2
excerpt: MTFP’s roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, March 29-April 2, from voting rights to transgender restrictions to marijuana regulation.

title: Citizens allege election discrepancy
excerpt: A records request for ballot envelopes in Missoula County has generated allegations about the 2020 election results, and given legislators fodder for debates about changing statewide election laws.

title: Social media oversight bill fails in Senate Committee
excerpt: A bill that seeks to put social media oversight under the state Public Service Commission’s purview was tabled by the Senate Energy and Telecommunications Committee this week, bringing an apparent end to the measure.

title: Trio of bills offer competing visions for recreational marijuana
excerpt: Three bills are competing to establish a framework for implementation of Montana’s recreational marijuana market. One has the governor’s backing.

title: Education’s federal relief windfall

nodes.name: Elementary and Secondary School Emergency Relief Fund

excerpt: Montana’s public schools are set to receive nearly $500 million in COVID-19 relief funds, with tens of millions more available at the state’s discretion. Where will the money go, and how will it be used to recover from the pandemic?

title: Restrictions on transgender athletes and expanded religious protections move closer to law
excerpt: Republican lawmakers this week advanced two bills that have been strenuously opposed by Democrats and advocates for LGBTQ civil rights.

title: Multibillion stimulus bill aims to spur Montana into post-COVID prosperity. Here’s what lawmakers want to spend.
excerpt: House Bill 632 directs a massive influx of cash, equivalent to about $2,800 per Montana resident, toward spending on infrastructure, business support, social services and education — investments that proponents say will help carry Montana into post-COVID prosperity.

title: On the governor’s behalf
excerpt: Lieutenant Governor Kristen Juras has long been known as a legal analyst with staunchly conservative social views. Now, she’s pulling the levers of policy in the state Capitol.

title: Bill advocate accuses Legislative Services of ‘fake legal advice’
excerpt: An Arizona man involved in Sen. Theresa Manzella’s social media regulation bill claims state attorneys are running scared of ‘Big Tech Boogey Man.’

title: The Session podcast
excerpt: What we’re looking forward to in week 13: Judges, elections and recreational marijuana

title: This week in Helena, March 22-26
excerpt: A roundup of this week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, from the budget to education to birth certificates.

title: Withholding energy assistance
excerpt: Senate Bill 237 would void fines incurred by NorthWestern Energy for its failure to follow the state’s renewable energy standards.

title: House forwards contentious voter ID bill
excerpt: House Bill 169 would add additional identification requirements that critics say would disenfranchise students, the elderly and indigenous Montanans.

title: A court divided?
excerpt: House Bill 325 would ask voters to approve election of state Supreme Court justices by districts, rather than statewide. Supporters say the change would encourage better representation on the state’s most powerful bench. Critics call it ‘judicial gerrymandering.’

title: A ‘wish list for NorthWestern’
excerpt: Senate Bill 379 could create a ‘glide path out of Colstrip’ — and put utility customers on the hook for $267 million in stranded costs.

title: Gianforte administration takes second crack at modernizing corporate income tax
excerpt: Gov. Greg Gianforte’s administration is renewing a push its officials have described as an effort to modernize Montana’s corporate income tax code to better reflect the state’s 21st-century economy, backing a new, less ambitious bill after a prior measure stalled in the face of industry opposition.

title: Bullock-appointed judges face questions in Senate confirmation
excerpt: Weeks after Gov. Greg Gianforte signed a bill overhauling the process for filling judicial vacancies, lawmakers on the Senate Judiciary Committee held confirmation hearings Wednesday for two judges appointed by former Gov. Steve Bullock.

title: Student count continues to dip
excerpt: Spring enrollment numbers show a continued decrease in public school students this spring, heightening the case for federal relief.

title: Budget bill advances on party lines
excerpt: The Republican majority in the Montana House advanced the main state budget bill Monday after fending off Democrats’ push for additional funds for social service programs.

title: The Session podcast
excerpt: Week 12: Tracking the budget in the House, a windfall of federal cash, and new rules for legalized marijuana.

title: This week in Helena, March 15-19
excerpt: MTFP’s roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, March 15-19, from stimulus spending to wildlife management.

title: The community college question
excerpt: As Montana looks to trade-based education to aid economic recovery, a suite of bills in the Legislature aims to bolster funding for those programs and potentially settle a lingering question over the Bitterroot’s ability to grow its own workforce.

title: Opposition digs in against LGBTQ bills, with Gianforte in the wings
excerpt: The coalition opposing bills restricting transgender health care and athletic participation is growing as critical votes approach.

title: Conservation groups blast marijuana bill that steers revenues into General Fund
excerpt: A draft version of the bill implementing recreational cannabis would send more money into the state General Fund and prohibit people from growing at home unless they have a medical marijuana card.

title: Stimulus money could fuel massive Montana broadband effort
excerpt: Department of Commerce Director Scott Osterman said Wednesday he’d like to see lawmakers put at least $350 million from Montana’s share of the new federal coronavirus relief package into a major initiative boosting broadband connectivity across the state.

title: Another try for charter schools
excerpt: HB 633 would authorize a public charter school system in Montana. Opponents questions the costs and benefits — and the necessity.

title: ‘Reimbursement’ or ‘bounty’?
excerpt: SB 267 would allow for reimbursement of hunting expenses, and SB 314 would remove bag limits and legalize baiting and spotlighting.

title: Gianforte signs bill allowing governors to appoint judges to vacant seats
excerpt: Gov. Greg Gianforte on Tuesday announced he has signed a controversial bill allowing Montana’s governor to directly appoint judges to fill temporary vacancies in district courts and the state Supreme Court, a marked change from the less partisan, independent process Montanans created after the 1972 Constitutional Convention.

title: Public ed and the Pledge
excerpt: HB 543 would require schools to instruct students in grades 3-12 about the U.S. Constitution, and mandate daily recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: The Session podcast
excerpt: Week 11: The state budget takes shape, and marijuana regulation is coming soon.

title: This week in Helena, March 8-12
excerpt: MTFP’s roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, March 8-12, from initiatives to taxes to tribal affairs.

title: House Republicans push for bigger income tax cut
excerpt: The Republican majority on Montana’s House Taxation Committee voted Friday to increase the amount of an income tax cut proposed by Gov. Greg Gianforte, more than doubling a reduction proposed for the state’s top tax bracket.

title: Raising the ballot initiative bar
excerpt: Two bills that would double the signature requirements to qualify initiatives for the ballot pass committee on party-line vote.

title: Gianforte administration signals support for religious expression bill
excerpt: The Gianforte administration is backing a controversial religious freedom bill strongly opposed by LGBTQ advocates.

title: Shifting gears with an education omnibus
excerpt: HB 46 proposes to enhance local control, strengthen work-based learning and address Montana’s teacher shortage, all at the same time.

title: Extending eligibility
excerpt: House Bill 612 aims to help high school seniors in Montana maintain access to financial assistance for higher education that may have been jeopardized by the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: New round of federal COVID-19 aid means billions for Montana
excerpt: Analysts expect Montana to see at least $2.7 billion in federal aid on top of $1,400 individual stimulus payments from the relief bill just passed by Congress.

title: The Session podcast
excerpt: Week 10: What made it, and what didn’t, through the halfway point of the Montana Legislature

title: Halfway home in Helena
excerpt: MTFP’s roundup of key action in the first two months of the 67th Montana Legislature.

title: Solutions status
excerpt: The Solutions Caucus has been a defining aspect of recent legislative sessions. But with stronger GOP majorities and a Republican governor, is that intra-party dynamic still alive in the 2021 Legislature?

title: Nuclear on the radar: Part II
excerpt: Montana legislators want to explore a new horizon for carbon-free nuclear energy in the state. Some environmental organizations and labor groups are on board.

title: How are Republicans spending their mandate?
excerpt: At the Legislature’s halfway point, lawmakers take stock and assess next steps.

title: Right-to-work fails muster
excerpt: Scores of union members kept watch as the Legislature killed two high-profile bills aimed at changing Montana labor laws.

title: Nuclear on the radar: Part I
excerpt: House Bill 273 would lay the groundwork for nuclear development in Montana — and take voters out of the mix.

title: House passes bills limiting authority of local health officials and governor
excerpt: House Bills 121 and 230 would give elected officials and legislators more oversight in emergency situations like the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Lawmaker reports ‘threatening’ texts
excerpt: Rep. Frank Garner alerted Capitol security Friday to texts he says appeared to reference his vote on a vaccination bill.

title: This week in Helena, Feb. 22-26
excerpt: MTFP’s roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, from wolves to taxes to vaccination.

title: Bill would expand Native voting rights as Republican lawmakers push restrictions
excerpt: House Bill 613 would address some barriers Indigenous voters face and protect them from legislation that would make it more difficult for them, and other groups, to vote.

title: Eliminating the enforcer
excerpt: House Bill 535 to the House State Administration Committee Thursday. The bill seeks to replace the governor-appointed Commissioner of Political Practices with a four-person bipartisan council selected by legislative leadership, and to transfer oversight of campaign finance reporting to the Secretary of State.

title: New bill would make it harder for transgender Montanans to amend their birth certificates
excerpt: Lawmakers on the Senate Judiciary Committee forwarded a bill Thursday that would increase requirements for a transgender person to change the gender listed on their birth certificate.

title: To require, or not to require
excerpt: A pair of bills in the Montana Legislature address vaccination

title: Increasing penalties for damaging energy infrastructure
excerpt: The House Judiciary Committee heard testimony this week on a bill that would create stiff penalties for defacing, damaging or tampering with oil and gas, mining, railway or telecommunications infrastructure.

title: ‘A punch in the gut when we were already down’
excerpt: Montana LGBTQ advocates are battling an unprecedented number of bills this Legislature they see as dangerous and discriminatory.

title: Republicans advance income tax cuts as Democratic measures are voted down
excerpt: Three bills backed by Gov. Greg Gianforte, reducing taxes for higher earners in an effort to stimulate the economy, advanced in the Montana Senate Tuesday.

title: Appointed-PSC proposal fails
excerpt: Senate Bill 160 — which would have shrunk the Public Service Commission to a three-member appointed body — is likely dead after down vote on second reading.

title: Lawmakers try again to deny medical treatments to trans youth
excerpt: For the second time this session, lawmakers on the House Judiciary Committee have forwarded a bill that would prohibit certain kinds of medical treatment for transgender and nonbinary youth. The proposal, which passed nearly along party lines, was the subject of emotional and frustrated testimony on Monday from parents, medical providers and advocates.

title: Rewilding the national mammal

nodes.name: Fort Peck Assiniboine and Sioux Tribes

excerpt: There’s a bottleneck of bison at brucellosis quarantine facilities outside of Yellowstone National Park. Two bills introduced by a Montana lawmaker could alleviate that, helping tribes across the U.S. restore viable wild herds. Will the Montana Legislature back them?

title: This week in Helena, Feb. 15-19
excerpt: A roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature, from public assistance to campaign finance to local control.

title: Nitpick or necessity?
excerpt: The biggest change in SB 224 is a repeal of Montana’s cap on candidate contributions from political committees.

title: Gianforte signs ‘constitutional carry’ gun bill
excerpt: HB 102 will let Montanans carry concealed firearms without a permit almost anywhere in the state.

title: Proposal to nullify local mask mandates advances
excerpt: Lawmakers advanced a bill Wednesday that would essentially nullify local health measures like mask mandates and prohibit local governments and health officials from adopting similar requirements in the future.

title: Lawmakers propose new requirements for Medicaid, SNAP eligibility

nodes.name: Department of Public Health and Human Services

excerpt: A suite of bills that would add new eligibility requirements for public assistance are generating controversy in the Montana Legislature.

title: Putting economic impacts on the PSC’s plate
excerpt: House Bill 314 would make Montana’s Public Service Commission consider the community consequences of coal-fired closures.

title: Labor at the Legislature

nodes.name: Montana Citizens for Right to Work

excerpt: The ‘right to work’ movement has resurfaced in Montana with a raft of bills in the 67th session. Proponents say the measures are ripe to spur economic growth in the wake of COVID-19, but a new study says right-to-work states lag in wage growth and worker protections.

title: This week in Helena, Feb. 8-12
excerpt: A roundup of the week’s key action in the 67th Montana Legislature.

title: Gianforte administration calls for tax cuts to lure out-of-state entrepreneurs
excerpt: Three bills before the Legislature would scale back income and capital gains taxes in an effort to bolster Montana’s economy by boosting entrepreneurs. Opponents don’t buy the logic.

title: Legislature’s American Indian Caucus pushes back on Haaland opposition
excerpt: Members of the Montana Legislature’s American Indian Caucus push back on Steve Daines and Matt Rosendale’s opposition to Biden’s Interior pick.

title: ‘Simple bill to safeguard federal lands’ or ‘red herring’?
excerpt: HB 320 would prevent the state from selling federal land, but opponents say it’s part of a larger land transfer effort.

title: Gianforte says he’ll lift state mask mandate this week
excerpt: Governor says a COVID-19 lawsuit shield bill and vaccination progress are adequate to end the face mask requirement enacted last year. Local jurisdictions will be allowed to implement their own mandates.

title: Debating integrity
excerpt: Legislators in the 2021 session agree that Montana elections should be fair and secure. But debate on proposals from both sides of the aisle has revealed powerful fallout from the 2020 election — and partisan disagreement on solutions.

title: Tribal leaders and landowners clash over hunting proposal
excerpt: House Bill 241 would end a decades-old prohibition against hunting on land within a reservation owned by non-Indians.

title: Senate Judiciary votes to forward anti-abortion bills
excerpt: House Bills 136, 140, 167 and 171 would restrict abortion and penalize medical providers in a variety of ways.

title: Business equipment tax cut gets initial hearing
excerpt: House Bill 303, sponsored by Rep. Josh Kassmier, R-Fort Benton, would raise the threshold where the state’s business equipment tax kicks in from $100,000 to $200,000.

title: Cutting out the judicial appointment middleman
excerpt: Senate Bill 140 would disband the Judicial Nomination Commission, giving the governor power to fill district court and Supreme Court vacancies by direct appointment.

title: Can Montana get a grip on addiction?

nodes.name: Department of Public Health and Human Services

excerpt: Gov. Gianforte says substance abuse is a crisis with ‘devastating consequences.’ His HEART Fund aims to improve perennial shortcomings in care. Health care experts see plenty of promise — and pitfalls.

title: Adding options and opportunity to public education
excerpt: Lawmakers hear supporting testimony on a bill to broaden education laws for students, local school officials and teachers.

title: Subdividing DEQ
excerpt: Senate Bill 165 would shift the Department of Environmental Quality’s subdivision rulemaking authority to the governor-appointed Board of Environmental Review

title: COVID liability shield clears Legislature
excerpt: SB 65, which protects businesses from many COVID-19-related lawsuits, is headed to the desk of Gov. Greg Gianforte, who has called it a necessary step toward lifting the state’s mask mandate.

title: Competing visions for the relationship between PSC and NorthWestern Energy
excerpt: The House Energy, Technology and Federal Relations Committee heard testimony on two bills Wednesday that could affect the relationship between NorthWestern Energy and Montana’s Public Service Commission.

title: Two bills look to reduce wolf populations
excerpt: If House Bills 224 and 225 pass, Montana will follow Idaho’s lead by extending the trapping season and allowing for the snaring of wolves.

title: Concealed carry expansion bill passes Senate
excerpt: HB 102, which expands the locations where Montanans can legally carry concealed firearms cleared the state Senate Wednesday, and is expected to head to the desk of Gov. Greg Gianforte.

title: Revising lethal injection — and reviving a death penalty in legal limbo
excerpt: House Bill 244 would strike the state’s current lethal injection requirements and broaden the variety of drugs Montana can use to execute death row inmates.

title: Repealing a tribal tax exemption
excerpt: SB 138 would repeal a tax exemption for tribal properties applying for federal trust status.

title: Making curbside alcohol sales permanent
excerpt: House Bill 226 would let businesses with alcohol licenses sell packaged alcohol and prepared mixed drinks to-go, extending temporary COVID rules.

title: Bill would end partisan balance on interim legislative committees
excerpt: Senate Bill 122 would give the Legislature’s majority party more control over interim committees that meet between sessions.

title: How to bring transparency to prescription drug prices?
excerpt: Under the proposal, prescription drug makers would be required to file an annual report with the state disclosing the wholesale price of any drugs sold in Montana.

title: Gianforte stresses ‘resilience’ in first State of the State address
excerpt: Tax policy, drug treatment and abortion restrictions top the governor’s priority list in his first address to the 67th Legislature.

title: Push to limit public health authorities continues
excerpt: HB 230 and HB 236, sponsored by Rep. Matt Regier, would restrain local health department authority in favor of elected officials during public health emergencies.

title: Lawmaker looks to ban ‘free-speech zones’ at public universities
excerpt: House Bill 218, which would ban “free-speech zones” on public university campuses. The measure’s sponsor, Rep. Mike Hopkins, R-Missoula, said the bill would prevent those institutions from restricting unsanctioned speech to a designated area of campus.

title: Anti-single-family-zoning bill gets tepid reception
excerpt: House Bill 134 would ban single-family zoning designations in Montana cities in an effort to boost affordability by encouraging more duplex, triplex and fourplex housing.

title: Lawmakers make another push to ban ‘sanctuary cities’
excerpt: The House Judiciary Committee heard testimony on HB 200, which would require local jurisdictions to work with federal immigration agencies if a non-citizen is detained, potentially leading to that person’s deportation.

title: HB 113 narrowly fails final House vote
excerpt: One day after House Bill 113 survived intense debate and a major vote on the House floor, the proposal failed to clear a procedural vote Tuesday after five Republicans reversed their stances, making the final vote count 49 in favor, 51 opposed. Advocates for transgender rights hailed the change as a significant win.

title: Proposing new road rules for cyclists
excerpt: House Bill 184 would require cyclists to wear high-visibility clothing on highways, and motorists to give cyclists at least three feet of distance when passing.

title: Raising teacher salaries
excerpt: House Bill 143 would create financial incentives for school districts to increase the salaries of teachers in their first three years in the profession.

title: MTFP launches 2021 Montana Capitol Tracker
excerpt: The 2021 Montana Capitol Tracker, a new digital guide from Montana Free Press, aims to help Montanans make sense of the business being conducted on their behalf during this year’s legislative session by presenting the quantifiable aspects of the Montana Legislature in an easy-to-use searchable interface.

title: Republican majority in House advances bills restricting abortion, transgender rights
excerpt: In a tense and emotionally charged floor session, the Montana House on Monday passed four bills seeking to curtail abortion access and two that restrict the rights of transgender youth and athletes.

title: Loosening regs around killing grizzlies
excerpt: Increasing numbers of bears — and bear conflicts — on the Rocky Mountain Front spark a bill to increase latitude for killing.

title: Labor rallies against ‘consent’ bill
excerpt: House Bill 168, sponsored by Rep. Bill Mercer, R-Billings. The measure would revise state labor laws to establish a consent agreement for public employees granting their employers permission to collect union-associated fees. That notification would have to be renewed annually.

title: Transgender restriction bills advance
excerpt: Lawmakers on the House Judiciary Committee have passed HB 112 and HB 113, largely along party lines.

title: ‘Keep hope alive’
excerpt: A slate of bills moving through the House and Senate would build on the work of the state’s Missing Indigenous Persons Task Force.

title: Same-day voter registration debated
excerpt: Lawmakers heard testimony framing a proposed end to same-day voter registration as either essential to election integrity or an assault on democracy.

title: Gianforte fills out cabinet

nodes.name: Montana Department of Labor and Industry
Montana Department of Natural Resources and Conservation

excerpt: The incoming governor’s picks include longtime Montana figures and hires with experience in other states.

title: First of multiple anti-abortion measures advance
excerpt: Republican lawmakers, encouraged by their party’s unified control of state government after the November elections, are advancing a number of bills that could, if enacted, dramatically limit access to abortions across Montana.

title: Public health authority debate continues
excerpt: Republican lawmakers are taking aim at the rule-making powers of public health boards and officers in response to COVID-19 precautions that critics say ignored other factors, like impacts to small businesses, without a way to contest those rules.

title: Lawmakers consider expanding affordable housing financing program
excerpt: Two years after passing a program designed to increase the number of affordable apartments available in Montana communities by letting housing developers use the state’s coal trust fund as a bank for low-interest loans, Montana lawmakers are considering doubling the funding available for the program.

title: Direct primary care debate resurfaces
excerpt: Sen. Cary Smith, R-Billings, introduced Senate Bill 101 to members of the Senate Business, Labor and Economic Affairs Committee, stating that the legislation would help strengthen relationships between health care providers and their patients and give Montanans access to another option for affordable health care.

title: Promoting rural broadband with tax breaks
excerpt: Senate Bill 51 aims to address a troublesome gap in Montana’s infrastructure: places where residents still don’t have access to reliable broadband internet.

title: Reviewing the regs
excerpt: House Bill 158 would establish a commission to do cost-benefit analysis of emergency regulatory changes prompted by COVID-19.

title: House committee hears emotional arguments on transgender bills
excerpt: In an emotional four-hour hearing Monday, advocates and opponents of transgender rights debated two bills before the House Judiciary Committee, setting the stage for a controversial vote later this week.

title: Transgender athlete bill to get a hearing Monday
excerpt: House Bill 112 has thrust Montana into a national debate over the rights of transgender athletes in public schools.

title: Making it right with the wrongfully convicted
excerpt: The House Judiciary Committee unanimously approved a bill Friday that would allow a person who’s been wrongly convicted and incarcerated to receive compensation from the state.

title: Ask first, shoot later
excerpt: The House Fish, Wildlife and Parks Committee approved a bill Thursday, Jan. 14, that significantly strengthens penalties for hunters who trespass on private property.

title: Lawmakers consider limiting authority of local health officials
excerpt: House Bill 121 would limit the authority of local public health boards, giving elected officials more power in setting public health policies.

title: Lawmakers debate local nicotine-product prohibitions
excerpt: In what opponents say is part of a larger push this session to pass laws favorable to the tobacco industry, legislators discussed a bill proposal Wednesday that would prevent local governments from regulating nicotine products ingested through devices like electronic cigarettes and vape pens.

title: Tense gun law debate continues on House floor
excerpt: The tense debate over a measure to expand the right to carry a concealed gun in Montana spilled onto the House floor Wednesday afternoon, at one point descending into a disagreement over decorum and halting the proceedings to clarify the appropriateness of a question posed by a lawmaker.

title: ‘Right-to-work’ returns

nodes.name: Montana Citizens for Right to Work

excerpt: Montana candidates didn’t have much to say about unions and labor law on the campaign trail, but a slate of bills and a new public-influence push show fresh energy behind a perennial Republican priority.

title: Allowing victims to record abusers
excerpt: HB 114 sponsor Mary Ann Dunwell said the bill could help ‘break the cycle of violence’ by expanding the tools available to prosecutors of domestic violence cases.

title: Checking a governor’s emergency powers
excerpt: Sponsor Rep. David Bedey said a bill heard in committee Jan. 12 is an effort to give the Legislature more authority to weigh in on executive action during extended crises.

title: ‘A little TLC’ for students under stress
excerpt: House Bill 27 sponsor Rep. Moffie Funk says ‘Handle with Care’ programs can help kids coping with traumatic incidents.

title: Transgender Montanans and allies prepare to fight medical bill
excerpt: Transgender Montanans and allies are preparing to defend access to critical medical care for minors experiencing gender dysphoria.

excerpt: Your guide to public participation during an unprecedented hybrid legislative session in Helena.

title: House Judiciary Committee approves bill allowing concealed carry on campuses.
excerpt: House Bill 102 passed on a party-line vote. The bill reduces legal restrictions governing open and concealed carry.

title: Senate holds hearing on COVID liability protections
excerpt: Montana Senate hears a bill that would shield public health compliant businesses from certain COVID-19-related lawsuits.

title: Legislature to get dedicated contact tracer
excerpt: Legislative COVID-19 panel: masks and temperature checks recommended but not required following legislator’s positive COVID test.

title: A new day at DEQ and DNRC

nodes.name: Department of Natural Resources and Conservation

excerpt: Gov. Gianforte has taken the first steps to reduce permitting times and state environmental regulations, naming new directors of the DEQ and DNRC.

title: Legislature announces lawmaker’s positive COVID test
excerpt: Hamilton Republican Rep. David Bedey, has tested positive for the coronavirus, legislative leadership said late Thursday.

title: Gianforte budget calls for multiple tax reductions
excerpt: Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte, sworn in to office Monday, unveiled his first two-year budget proposal Thursday, saying the state can provide tax relief and invest in some of his priorities while leaving its reserve accounts healthy.

title: Gianforte signals support for state pay plan proposal
excerpt: Newly sworn-in Republican Gov. Greg Gianforte’s administration signaled Wednesday that the governor intends to support a compensation proposal before the Montana Legislature that would hold state workers’ wages flat over the coming year and then offer raises in the second half of calendar year 2022.

title: Pro-public health and anti-mask contingents hold concurrent rallies on opening day
excerpt: Members of the public encouraging legislators to follow Lewis and Clark County public health measures including masking, social distancing and avoiding large gatherings coincided with protesters calling for a loosening of those regulations and a mask-free state outside of the Capitol as the 67th regular session of the Montana Legislature convened Monday morning.

title: 2021 Legislature convenes in a crowded Capitol
excerpt: Members of the House and Senate kicked off the 2021 Legislature in person at the state Capitol on Monday, formally convening and electing leadership for what may be a turbulent 90-day session during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: The stories of 2020
excerpt: It was a year of change and challenge, from COVID to the campaign trail to the Capitol and beyond. Here are some reader favorites, and some of our own, from a year to remember.

title: Lawmakers anxious, excited ahead of 2021 session
excerpt: Many state lawmakers are preparing to step foot in the Capitol building next week. Others are planning to work remotely given the risks of spreading COVID-19 indoors.

title: Legislative session will be in-person and virtual, per Rules Committee
excerpt: Lawmakers bypassed the most proactive measures to protect public health, but will allow for remote participation for legislators and the public.

title: Rules maneuvers hint at a potential hardline coup in the House
excerpt: Republicans have unified control of the statehouse. With COVID complicating procedures, the party’s right flank could angle for primacy.

title: Nipped in the bud?
excerpt: Many conservative lawmakers oppose the legalization of marijuana, an illegal drug under federal law. But they are discovering obstacles to simply passing bills to reverse the initiatives when state legislatures return to work in January. Some marijuana opponents, realizing the limitations to altering a constitutional amendment, are turning to the courts or local officials to undo the measures or at least blunt the effects of legal pot.

title: Gianforte holds first press conference
excerpt: During a Friday press conference, his first since being elected, Gov.-elect Greg Gianforte offered few hints about what policies he may pursue or support once he’s sworn in on Jan. 4.

title: Gianforte picks ‘full-spectrum conservative’ as lead lawyer
excerpt: Gov.-elect Greg Gianforte announced Monday that Anita Milanovich will serve as general counsel in his incoming administration, appointing her as the chief lawyer tasked with shepherding his political agenda.

title: Gianforte names U.S. Attorney as budget director
excerpt: Kurt Alme, currently Montana’s top federal prosecutor, will manage the budget for a governor who has promised fiscal restraint.

title: COVID and the Capitol
excerpt: This week’s leadership caucuses at the Montana Capitol raised the specter of flouted health directives, but rules for the upcoming session remain to be set.

title: Newly elected lawmakers pick leaders for 2021 session
excerpt: Newly elected Republican legislative leaders promised to help colleagues advance an agenda they said has long been stymied by Democratic governors.

title: Politicos explain Montana’s red wave
excerpt: In interviews with Montana Free Press, nearly a dozen elected officials, campaign strategists, and political analysts described what they believe are the reasons behind the results, citing the popularity of President Trump and national attacks against the Democratic Party and the COVID-19 pandemic’s economic fallout and the ways in which the virus complicated campaign strategy.

title: How will the GOP spend its mandate?
excerpt: With the governor’s office and an expanded legislative majority, Republicans will be in the driver’s seat come the 2021 Montana Legislature. But the party’s leaders say they’re still honing their agenda.

title: Shared State
excerpt: In this final episode of Shared State: who won the election, what do the results say about Montana, and where are we headed?

title: How Montanans voted, precinct by precinct
excerpt: Record-breaking turnout colored much — but not all — of Montana red this year. As vote counting draws to a close, explore the results with our interactive map.

title: Lawmakers spar over legislative rules

nodes.name: Joint senate and house rules committee

excerpt: Republican lawmakers from the Joint Senate and House Rules Committee met Thursday in an unusual effort to propose changes to legislative rules before the 2021 session. Democratic lawmakers boycotted the meeting, insisting that it was illegitimate.
